content.description: This exceptionally fine steep crack is any trad climbers dream, with great gear, hard moves, clean rock, safe falls, and best of all pump factor that keeps you desperatly jamming with lactic acid bloated arms until the very end.  Every gear placement can be seen from the ground, taking finger-to hand sized peices in the lower roof, do a fun technical steep crux, thread your fingers the natural ring and place a fist sized piece, and traverse out the last part of the roof doing gaston hand jams and clever footwork to pull around the corner to a nice 5.7 crack to the top.
content.protection: (In BD Camalots) doubles from #0.3s to #2s, and one #3 (fist-sized) for the middle of the roof.  There is an old sling at the top, which is looking a bit worst for wear, with a quicklink.  Bolted anchor anyone? Or shall we replace it with another sling to rot?
content.location:
Right in the middle of the sport cliff, this is the obvious, steep roof crack just left of Fiddler Under the Roof, and right of

The Albatross

.

content.description:
The climb ascends a left-facing dihedral on the left side of the crag. A #2 RP protects the moves to the lone bolt (or stickclip). A technical stemming crux leads up the smooth dihedral past the bolt to 5.9 climbing with good protection. Finish over a tiny roof or bulge.

The crux bolt should be replaced, if it hasn't already. You have my permission to add a 2 bolt anchor at the top. This was the second 5.12 established in the canyon.
content.protection: 1 bolt (1/4" diameter), a #2 RP (or BD steel nut), a #5 RP (#6 BD steel nut), and a #9 stopper to #1 Camalot.
content.location:
It is right of

Ecstasy & Wise Guys

and left of

Albatross

.

content.description: Start off under the roof and reach up into the lieback finger crack. Getting out of the overhang and into the crack is the crux. Crank up good locks on increasingly good feet to a sit down ledge. Climb up through slopey ledges to a two bolt anchor with chains.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3", doubles in finger sizes.
content.location:
This is the last route on the right of the main face before it turns the corner to the

Home Field Advantage

. Look for a beautiful finger crack in a left-facing dihedral. You've found it.

content.description: Encompassing a myriad of features, moves, and difficulties, Killuminati is an excellent hard route that will demand your best bouldering and trad skills to scale the underbelly and headwall of this beast.  Start with a four star V7 or V8 boulder problem out the bulge on excellent rock over huge moves between incut edges, slopers, and side-pulls to the final crux throw to a sloping, half pad crimp. Hold the barn door swing, then fire into the gradually easier, 5.10 finger crack to anchors at the ledge.  This is a well-protected mixed route that is worth the efforts of any hard man in the area....
content.protection: Two bolts, multiple small wires and nuts, a couple finger-sized cams.
content.location: This is the overhanging bulge to crack  with two bolts between Demond Dyno (on the left) and The Leaner (on the right).

content.description: Between Trout Fishing in America and Warmup Corner, this mixed route begins by climbing up a cool, moderate boulder problem past the first bolt through water scoops then angles up right to the crack.  A crux hits 2/3rd of the way up, involving a large throw or desperate finger crack climbing, and is protected by a 000 Black Diamond C3.  Finish up left at anchors in the large water pod.
content.protection: 1 bolt, doubles set of small TCUs to a green Camalot.
content.location: This is between Trout Fishing in America and the Warmup Corner, on the right side of the Sports Crag.

content.description: As with many routes on this wall, The Albatross is an incredible classic splitter crack that takes high quality stone through three distinct cruxes and a kneebar rest through one of the cleanest panels of stone on the wall.  Gnarly fingers and hard jamming hit you right off the deck, but keep with it and you'll be rewarded with some of the most fun and dynamic face moves on the wall.
content.protection: Small stoppers, TCUs, a couple draws (for the fixed pin) and some medium sized gear (BD #0.5-1s) for the top.
content.location:
Left of

Shock the Monkey

, the obvious finger splitter that goes through the small roof past the fixed pin.
